posts.name:
Matt Bowker
Matt Bowker
posts.content:
Urban infill sites offer great opportunities to build more homes sustainably. For example, we've helped our client transform this site from two dwellings into 10 homes.

We are big fans of urban infill housing developments and here are 8 reasons why:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Efficient Use of Resources:

Infill development maximises existing infrastructure, including roads, utilities, and services; it reduces the need for new construction and minimises costs.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Efficient Use of Land:

By focusing on infill, cities can make more efficient use of previously developed (brownfield) land.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Reduced Urban Sprawl:

By focusing on infill, cities can contain their outward growth to preserve surrounding greenfields and prevent encroachment into natural habitats and agricultural land.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Enhanced Public Transport Accessibility:

Infill sites are typically located near existing public transport networks, promoting the use of mass transit and reducing reliance on cars, which lowers greenhouse gas emissions.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Revitalisation of Underutilised Areas:

Developing infill sites can rejuvenate neglected or declining neighbourhoods, boost local economies, and improve residents' quality of life.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Walkability & Community:

Higher-density developments encourage walkable neighbourhoods, foster community interactions, and reduce dependence on automobiles, which can enhance social cohesion.

7Ô∏è‚É£ Environmental Benefits:

By preserving green spaces and reducing the need for infrastructure expansion, infill development contributes to lower energy consumption, reduced habitat destruction, and supporting biodiversity.

8Ô∏è‚É£ Economic Strengthening:

Infill development can lead to increased property values and tax revenues, providing funds for public services and community enhancements that ultimately benefit the local economy.

These reasons underscore the importance of prioritising urban infill as a strategy for delivering more affordable homes, creating stronger communities, promoting sustainable urban development, and preserving green spaces.

The development shown is the Saplings, a residential development by our client PIC Homes comprising 10 large-family homes in Timperley, Trafford.

comments.commentText:
Sustainable Homes at 'offers over ¬£900k'! Yes, very sutainable....

The AIA for the site was weak at best. It didn't report on required mitigation i.e. trees for trees lost... Your landscaping plan is laughable! 29 trees removed including beech, limes, sycamore (large natives) and 'replaced' with 16 small ornamentals like Amelanchier and Photinia and the like. This is Green Washing at it's finest! Shame on Trafford Council for allowing a development of this nature to go ahead.

10 'Family Homes', yes like the average family can afford a property over ¬£900K... do yourself a favour and say it like it is... Profit rules all

Phil Donovan, PhD It‚Äôs from a US source and there is evidence form cities like Austin that have built lots of homes that prices and rents have gone down as a result.

Problem is we haven‚Äôt built anywhere near enough homes in the UK for decades so that, in conjunction with other factors like extremely low interest rates, has meant prices keep going up.

Matt Bowker sound like Trickle Down Economics! 

That has worked well hasn't it? Not!

You are clearly very proud of your achievement & looking forward to ¬£10 million payout once sold  

I'm perplexed why "we" believe there's a housing crisis though. It is a term often used to soften the feeling of guilt I've discovered.

 Go & visit somewhere in Cornwall like Port Issac for example. How many homes are holiday homes v actual residential lived-in homes  I reckon you would find it very difficult to find a real home. Housing is definitely abundant in Port Issac but they're all empty at the moment because it's all about the money  I went to visit to see for myself just in case I was being naive about what I was told. Yep, I couldn't find locals living in the village!

You must have missed this BBC News reel about the glut of empty houses in the UK to consider using the word 'crisis'. So I have attached a link for your convenience.

Shame about the trees; irreplaceable habitat in our lifetime but yeah, it won't keep you awake at night.

What's uncontrolled overgrowth? It's another way of you expressing your feeling of controlling other living organisms perhaps?

You're seeking acceptance. That's how I interpreted this post. No malice intended.
David Hague There are but my point is it‚Äôs a lot more expensive and difficult to buy a house now than when you and l bought our 1st house.

posts.name:
Alex Nelson
Alex Nelson
posts.content:
First AE hired. Zero pipeline. No playbook. Just me staring at an empty CRM wondering if I'd made a huge mistake.

Here's my honest story of those first 45 days:

‚Ä¢ Week 1-2: Studied the product, started running campaigns & doing mock demos.

‚Ä¢ Week 3-4: Started taking sales calls some better than others & expanded to other outreach channels.

‚Ä¢ Week 5-6: Felt pretty alone at times but started seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. Other AEs had teammates, but I was testing everything by myself.

‚Ä¢ Week 7+ (Present): Averaging a little over 6 demos per day & hitting the ground running prospecting every morning

What I learned:
1. Write down everything - my mistakes will help myself & others avoid them
2. Accept the chaos - good systems start messy
3. Make friends first, sell second - early customers help shape everything.

Being first is a challenge for sure but I'm having fun with it.

Founding AEs: What was your biggest "I wish someone told me this" moment?

PS- Happy Friday! Cheers!

comments.commentText: Every day I see dorks saying not to take the first sales hire job. Congrats on taking it. No matter what happens, you'll come out the other end a better man.

Cory Bray Winner. At one point it felt like I had to choose between two things:
1) Betting on myself
2) Doing something safe

Can't tell you how many people have told me how risky it was. But when I see someone or something totally disruptive and in the best way possible, I'm looking to get involved.

Thats what I saw here and ive honestly if anything only been more impressed. My decision is such a proud one at this point in retrospect but truly there was never another option
Cory Bray They sound like cowards

posts.content:
If you run an agency and have a lot of trouble productizing your service and making it repeatable you should probably use Motion.

Underrated how it almost punishes you for spending time to create something that is a single use project while simultaneously rewarding you for creating something repeatable/executable/understandable by others.

Everyone at B2B Catalyst has used several platforms for project management but I can say that it's probably the only one I've used that is built to get you more clarity quickly.

comments.commentText: Innnteresting. Haven‚Äôt used the tool but get ads for it‚Ä¶all‚Ä¶the‚Ä¶time. Your charactization actually makes me finally want to jump in.

Rex Harris We onboarded the team to it within 2 days. Took a little time to sink in but the AI scheduling for tasks/priorities is great at a granular level. Adds the right amount of micromanagement to the execution part but feeds back into templates you can deploy future iterations off of
Interesting take, any specific example?

posts.name:
Guillaume Moubeche
Guillaume Moubeche
posts.content:
Here are 5 things I did because I trusted my guts and not the people around me:

1- Started lemlist in the most saturated market ever
In 2018, there were thousands of sales automation platforms on the market.
No one understood why I wanted to start in such a crowded market.
After running an outbound sales agency and using most tools in that market, I felt like I could create something different to help more people succeed with outbound.

2- Launch multi-product strategy when everyone was telling me it was a loss of focus
In 2019, I started a side project while lemlist was growing 2 digits month over month (>30% MoM)
Everyone told me that it was a de-focus.
18 months later, I sold that project, and today 4 of the SaaS I run do more than $2M in ARR 

3- Let enterprise customers go
In 2020 I closed a few deals with enterprise customers.
On paper, it‚Äôs awesome.
No churn, high expansion, yearly upfront payment‚Ä¶
But in the end it didn‚Äôt fit our ICP nor the product we wanted to build at the time.
Letting go of some customers is hard but can be necessary in the long run.

4- Choose the deal that didn‚Äôt have the best terms.
In 2021, we had a lot of VCs and investors reach out with INSANE terms.
Since we didn‚Äôt want to raise, they were all OK to do 100% cash out (which means that money goes directly to our bank account as founder and not to the company‚Äôs bank out)
I received a few term sheets and LOI (letter of intent) but I didn‚Äôt choose the one with the best terms
I chose the one I felt the most comfortable with because I valued the relationship we had built withand

5- Acquire a tech company while having 0 knowledge about M&A
In 2022, I acquired Taplio when it was doing $20,000 in MRR
Today it‚Äôs doing more than $5,000,000 in ARR, and I believe that it will help even more creator around the world grow their business while leveraging their personal brand.

What about you?

What are the things you did because you knew better?

comments.commentText:
Thank you for your insights 

the "3- Let enterprise customers go" highly resonate with us right now.

With Cardynale We have to chose today between build the core value of the product or make requirement for enterprise customer (SOC2, SSO, custom integrations etc..).

We decided that we prefer to focus first on the core value. And maybe one day we will decide to serve these customers.

I‚Äôm a bit of a fatalist when it comes to the first point - if you‚Äôre going to give it a shot, why not aim high, even in the most saturated markets? Who knows, maybe your destiny is to stand out as number 1!

Askar Ali üåø
Askar Ali üåø
posts.content:
How to Spot the Difference Between Authentic and Counterfeit Products

In today‚Äôs market, one might assume everything in their wardrobe is original, but counterfeits are more common than we think‚Äîespecially for popular brands.

Understanding the differences between genuine and counterfeit items is crucial to ensure you‚Äôre not paying for something less than what you expect.

Take Nike Air sneakers, for example. Authentic pairs have specific qualities that counterfeit manufacturers struggle to replicate:
‚Ä¢ Material Quality: Genuine Nike Air sneakers use high-quality materials that result in a distinct texture, particularly in the leather. Counterfeits often lack this hardness and durability.
‚Ä¢ Symmetry: Authentic sneakers are designed with precision, ensuring perfect symmetry. Any asymmetry could be a red flag.

Being aware of these details can save you from being misled and ensure you‚Äôre investing in authentic, high-quality products.

What steps do you take to verify authenticity before making a purchase? Let‚Äôs discuss!

comments.commentText: This is the same shoe in each photo.

Bob Drapeau The differences in the photo between the fake and original Nike shoes are:
 1. Logo Alignment:
 ‚Ä¢ Fake: The ‚ÄúNIKE AIR‚Äù logo is not well-centered and appears misaligned.
 ‚Ä¢ Original: The ‚ÄúNIKE AIR‚Äù logo is properly aligned and centered.
 2. Heel Texture:
‚Ä¢ Fake: The heel area lacks texture and looks smoother than it should.
‚Ä¢ Original: The heel area has a textured finish, consistent with the authentic design.
3. Construction Quality:
‚Ä¢ Fake: The stitching and finish around the heel area look less precise.
‚Ä¢ Original: The stitching and finish are clean and precise.
Askar Ali  same shoe in both pic
I would debate ‚Äúhigh quality.‚Äù My son wears Nike for basketball. They last maybe 2-3months.

posts.name:
Inc42 Media
Inc42 Media
posts.content:
D2C fashion startup The Souled Store turned profitable in the financial year ended March 2024 (FY24) on the back of a strong growth in its top line and improvement in margins. The startup posted a net profit of INR 18.2 Cr during the year under review as against a loss of INR 16.5 Cr in FY23

Operating revenue surged 54.26% to INR 360.2 Cr from INR 233.5 Cr in FY23. It earned INR 5.2 Cr from membership fees, while the rest of the revenue came from the sale of products.

Founded in 2013 by,,and Harsh Lal, The Souled Store started as a branded merchandise apparel brand and later morphed into its current D2C casual wear brand form.

To read the in-depth article, click here:

comments.commentText:
The Souled Store‚Äôs transformation from a ‚Çπ16.5 Cr loss in FY23 to an ‚Çπ18.2 Cr profit in FY24 is the kind of pivot that startup dreams (and investor presentations) are made of. 


With revenue soaring 54% to ‚Çπ360.2 Cr, it‚Äôs clear they‚Äôve tapped into the zeitgeist of India‚Äôs casually stylish youth, who now seem to wear their disposable incomes as effortlessly as their oversized T-shirts.

The ‚Çπ5.2 Cr from membership fees is particularly poetic‚Äîessentially monetizing loyalty while building a subscriber base that‚Äôs both fashionable and, evidently, financially useful.

For a brand rooted in "soul," this shift from merchandise kitsch to profit-savvy casual wear might seem paradoxical. But in today‚Äôs D2C landscape, perhaps the greatest flex is proving you can make margins as sharp as your marketing.

In essence, The Souled Store isn‚Äôt just selling clothes‚Äîit‚Äôs selling a lifestyle, and for once, it‚Äôs the startup, not the customer, leaving with fuller pockets.

The Souled Store‚Äôs profitability is a testament to the power of evolving with market trends and consumer preferences.

From branded merchandise to a full-fledged D2C casual wear brand, their ability to pivot and scale speaks volumes about the founders‚Äô vision and adaptability. Achieving a 54% growth in revenue while posting a net profit after a loss the previous year is no small feat, and it highlights the importance of smart strategy and operational excellence.

The fact that their membership fees contributed to a chunk of their revenue also opens interesting avenues for recurring revenue models in the D2C space. As we see more brands move towards personalized and community-driven experiences, The Souled Store's ability to build a loyal consumer base will be key to maintaining long-term growth.

Looking forward to seeing how they continue to innovate and expand in the future!

posts.name:
Victoria Tollossa
Victoria Tollossa
posts.content:
I‚Äôve failed more times than I can count.
I've started 6 companies. Only 2 worked out.

(Ok, maybe I can count them.)

Here‚Äôs the thing: most things we try will fail.
BUT... (and that‚Äôs a big but )

That doesn‚Äôt mean we are failures.

You are not defined by a project, a job, a relationship, or any single chapter of your life.

Keep going.
Keep growing.
Success is about resilience, not perfection.

comments.commentText:
Yes!

Every success is laced with failure. 

This is my big message to anyone (including myself) creating sales and marketing intiatives and plans.
